intro: Serratula coronata var. koreana, commonly known as Korean crownwort, is a perennial herb native to the mountainous regions of Korea. It belongs to the Asteraceae family, characterized by its composite flower heads and serrated leaf margins. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, with hairy stems and basal rosettes of lanceolate, serrated leaves. Its showy yellow flowers bloom in late summer, attracting pollinators such as bees and butterflies. It is often found in rocky or gravelly habitats and is valued for its ornamental appeal in horticulture.
